Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Direct Measurement and Identification of Individual Oxidized Mercury Compounds
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mercury is a neurotoxin and global pollutant that is currently not well understood. Specifically, identifying the individual compounds of gaseous oxidized mercury (GOM) is important for understanding the global chemical mercury cycle. Thus far, the measurement of specific atmospheric GOM compounds has not been possible. A large portion of mercury emissions comes from coal-fired power plants (CFPPs) where GOM compounds are emitted. This project is designed to identify individual GOM compounds that are typically found in Chinese CFPPs. This project will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Shuxiao Wang at Tsinghua University, China's leader in mercury/CFPP research, on methods of analyzing and identifying mercury compounds. Conducting this project in China is vital for understanding how much and what kind of mercury compounds are emitted because those compounds both enter our food supply (via predatory fish) and are transported across the Pacific to the United States.

GOM can be captured and analyzed from the effluent flue gas created by the drop-tube furnace. A drop-tube furnace will be used to simulate the emissions from a CFPP. During this project, gas samples will be taken off of the drop-tube furnace and analyzed for individual GOM compounds. Different forms of coal will be burned in the drop-tube furnace over the course of the study to get a better understanding of which GOM compounds are emitted. Samples taken from the drop-tube furnace will then be analyzed with a Gas Chromatograph-Mass Spectrometer to identify the principle GOM compounds for each coal type. Samples will also be taken from the flue gas of an existing CFPP outside Beijing to provide real-world verification. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mercury is a neurotoxin and global pollutant that, currently, is not well understood. Increasing our understanding of mercury in the atmosphere improves our ability to regulate emissions of mercury for public safety. Specifically, identifying compounds of gaseous oxidized mercury (GOM) is important for understanding how mercury behaves in the atmosphere. A large portion of anthropogenic mercury emissions come from coal-fired power plants, where GOM compounds are emitted. Although the United States may be cleaning up mercury output from coal-fired power plants, this will not affect the main source of mercury consumption for U.S. citizens. This source is consumption of predatory fish from the Pacific Ocean and a large percentage of the mercury that is found in these fish is believed to originate from coal-fired power plants in East Asia. Currently, methods for the measurement of GOM are problematic because they give no information on GOM compounds in the atmosphere. In order to advance the current understanding of how mercury behaves in the atmosphere and how it eventually makes its way to the fish we eat, advances in the detection and analysis of GOM must be made.

 

During my time in the EAPSI China Program, I was able to test the amount of GOM in coal-fired power plant flue gas by using a laboratory simulation called a drop-tube furnace which is located at Tsinghua University in Beijing, China. This machine is able to simulate a coal-fired power plant by burning coal like a power plant does, but with much lower quantities. We sampled off of this machine using traps which are used to collect GOM in the atmosphere. We also used these traps when we took samples of GOM from a coal-fired power plant outside of Beijing. In order to analyze these samples and find the types of GOM in flue gas, we used a gas chromatograph and mass spectrometer (GC-MS). We used this instrument because it does not break down the original structure of GOM we are testing during analysis. During the course of this project we discovered that the traps used to collect GOM in the atmosphere are efficient at collecting GOM, but inefficient at releasing it for us to analyze with a GC-MS. We were also able to create an analysis method using the GC-MS to identify GOM compounds which can benefit public health in the future.

 

Understanding the types and amount of GOM is an important piece of how mercury behaves in the atmosphere. We use atmospheric models to estimate the amount of mercury in the atmosphere, identify where mercury is transported, and to determine where mercury will get deposited which affects human health. Currently, these models are biased low based on the fact that we understand very little about how mercury behaves in the atmosphere. With the GC-MS methods developed during the EAPSI China program, we can continue adding to our limited understanding of how mercury behaves in the atmosphere. This will, in turn, allow us to build better controls for the reduction of mercury in the atmosphere and allow us to develop more efficient regulations on heavy metals for the wellbeing of the public.
